Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Automatic Generation of As-Built BIM Models Using a Single Video Camera
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will be to transform commercial construction through the democratization of scanning and automation of Building Information Modeling (BIM). Constant design and change management is a unique challenge that is costing the US construction industry billions of dollars annually. In order to prevent such a huge economic loss, this industry is in the path for a digital revolution. BIM is known as the first truly global digital technology that could revolutionize the construction industry. However, BIM usage is currently limited because it is only viable for large-scale projects. The primary reason is that the process is too laborious and expensive. The proposed technology will completely eliminate these barriers. Its ease-of-use, ubiquity of the capturing device, and automated object detection democratizes as-built BIM modeling. Enormous value could be generated due to streamlining and data management capabilities that are offered by the technology in the form of accelerated project schedules, reduced numbers of requests for information and change orders, and timely identified design clashes. This will pave the way to increase the competitiveness of the US construction industry, by enabling new products and services that support automatic BIM modeling.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project investigates the technical and commercial feasibility of an automatic and inexpensive solution for the Scan-to-BIM problem in the construction industry. Scan-to-BIM refers to 3D scanning of a physical structure and converting the captured raw spatial data into an object-oriented, semantically-rich model. Although there are a few technologies that aim to facilitate this process, the 3D modeling component remains primarily a manual and time-consuming task. When using the proposed technology, a non-technical worker videotapes the target structure. The video is automatically sent to a server for processing. A unique videogrammetric 3D reconstruction engine reconstructs the 3D geometry of the structure in the form of a 3D point cloud. It then extracts object hypotheses from key video frames and spatial data in the form of observations. Afterwards, it optimizes a novel coherent joint probability distribution function and infers a 3D layout. The outcome is an object-oriented 3D representation of the structure with embedded geometrical attributes and property sets. The main novelty of this technology lies in a hybrid approach that combines low-level segmentation with high-level space modeling. This advances the state-of-the-art in robust intelligence, particularly the interpretation of complex, unstructured data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Building Information Modeling (BIM) is a process that generates an object-oriented, digital representation of a physical structure and its functional characteristics to be used through the lifecycle of a project. Despite significant progress in 3D reconstruction of existing built environments, there is still no solution to reliably generate 3D models that accurately represent geometry, topology, and semantics all together. A valid and complete 3D digital model must include three components: a) geometry which defines boundary, shape, and dimensions of individual objects; b) topology which defines the relationships among building components; and c) semantics which defines additional characteristics through dedicated attributes (e.g., material type, functionality, cost information, etc.). Existing as-built BIM modeling solutions receive a laser-scanned 3D point cloud as the input data and identify a set of points that follow geometrical properties of primitive shapes; these points are then segmented from the point cloud and replaced by an object that represents the extracted geometry. Such solutions result in detailed geometrical information for objects with primitive geometry but fall short in extracting geometry of complex objects. Significant human intervention is therefore needed to segment the points which belong to complex objects.

The ultimate objective of this SBIR project was to investigate the technical and commercial feasibility of automating the entire process of so-called “Scan-to-BIM” by using inexpensive, off-the-shelf cameras. We validated a groundbreaking technology to address this problem through four technical steps/levels including 3D reconstruction engine, geometry, topology, and semantics. When using this technology, a video stream (or a set of overlapping imagery) is recorded of a structure using a camera. This camera could be of any type or form. The 3D reconstruction component of the technology processes each and every frame of the video to recover the camera trajectory and the 3D geometry of the structure. Given these data, several 2D/3D observations are formulated. Scene components/objects are detected and described in 3D and a BIM model is inferred.

During the Phase II project, a hybrid approach was developed and tested to combine low-level segmentation with high-level space modeling; this transformed the inference of the BIM model into a narrow interpretation space. A novel coherent joint probability function was also formulated such that it combined 2D and 3D data in a single formulation which enabled reasoning at the geometrical level. The project finally aimed to improve and perfect the computer vision and machine learning algorithms corresponding to the geometry, topology, and semantics steps to production-level code. The entire process was broken down into evolutionary steps, enabling the technology to initially solve problems with the least complexity and methodically progress into problems with higher level of complexity. Through supplementary projects, the technology was tailored towards an ideal solution for the roofing market through a strong partnership. The partners successfully commercialized this technology by providing the ability to process data from laser or image-based 3D scans, automatically extract roof geometry, and enable customers to review the output, visually confirm, and if necessary, manually verify accurate data and measurements. Moreover, the technical and commercial foundation for a successful commercial roof asset management program was built. These roofs are constantly exposed to environmental elements more than any other component of a building and hence preserving their long-term integrity is vital. Thus far, our progress enables commercial roof owners and facility managers to perform in-depth non-invasive visual inspection of readily accessible systems and components using aerial and drone imagery, minimizing the need for putting boots on the roof.
